title: Spain's Expo Osaka 2025 pavilion transports visitors into the depths of the ocean
author: Nathaniel Bahadursingh
excerpt: With the ocean as its narrative thread, the Spanish Pavilion at the 2025 World Expo in Osaka, Japan guides visitors through an immersive seascape. Image: archexist Designed by EXTUDIO, ENORME Studio, and Smart & Green Design under the theme “The Kuroshio Current”, the Spanish Pavilion is the...
text: With the ocean as its narrative thread, the Spanish Pavilion at the 2025 World Expo in Osaka, Japan guides visitors through an immersive seascape. Image: archexistDesigned by EXTUDIO, ENORME Studio, and Smart & Green Design under the theme “The Kuroshio Current”, the Spanish Pavilion is the result of a design selected through a competition organized by Acción Cultural Española. Its connection to the ocean refers to Spain’s national identity, as well as the country’s historical ties with Japan. Image: archexistThe pavilion spans approximately 37,674 square feet, showcasing Spain’s innovation, culture, and productive activity. Over the next six months, companies, regional authorities, and other institutions will use its spaces for meetings, presentations, and forums. Image: archexistThe pavilion features an open and welcoming architecture that doesn’t rely on an imposing façade. It is designed as a landscape that invites visitors into a spacious front void. This space or square is inspired by the Mediterranean spirit, which encourages play, rest, and interaction. As stated by the design team, “We wanted people to sit, relax, meet... almost like sitting by the seashore.” Image: archexistGentle steps that simulate sea waves lead visitors to the anteroom of the exhibition, which is called the Plaza del Sol. This space features an LED screen displaying seven video artworks that explore the symbolism of the sun.  Image: archexistImage: archexistBehind this “digital façade”, the exhibition opens up along a descending ramp that evokes the sensation of a dive. Ultramarine tones decorate this route, which leads to the exit, where a multipurpose room, a shop, and a seafood restaurant are located.  Image: archexistImage: archexistLocated at street level, the exit features a more vivid color palette and a 360º audiovisual installation that channels the festive spirit of Spain and its people. The exit is also connected to The Grand Ring, a vast wooden ring structure that houses the expo’s main facilities, designed by Sou Fujimoto Architects. Image: archexistIn response to the requirement that all structures at the expo be dismantled once the exhibition ends, the Spanish Pavilion was designed with future disassembly and potential reuse in mind. Its construction system relies on natural, locally sourced materials, such as Japanese red cedar wood, simple dry-assembled joints, and the use of a single element to address multiple needs. Image: archexistImage: archexistWood is used throughout the portico structure, composed of a double pillar at each end and T-shaped beams, repeated up to forty times at varying heights to shape the sequence of the interior volumes. The choice of material facilitates assembly and reduces the weight of the structure. Its foundation is, thus, simplified on the site, which contributes to minimizing the structure’s environmental footprint. Image: archexistThe design team collaborated with expert craftsmen for various components of the project, such as its colored façade pieces and furniture. Sustainability guidelines were defined with the support of companies specializing in waste management, who collectively advised the process and provided sustainable materials, such as partition panels made from recycled paper and interior finishes made from plastic recovered from fishing nets. Image: archexistImage: archexistIn addition to Plaza del Sol, the pavilion’s visitor experience is divided into three other sections. Corrientes hacia el futuro evokes the feeling of diving into the depths of the sea, with an interior that features audiovisual installations and interactive devices that explore the blue economy and Spain’s relationship with the ocean.  Image: archexistGreetings from Spain captures the festive and colorful nature of Spain’s landscapes and traditions, and Una España diversa presents a walkthrough highlighting the country’s regional diversity.
html:
With the ocean as its narrative thread, the Spanish Pavilion at the 2025 World Expo in Osaka, Japan guides visitors through an immersive seascape.

Designed by EXTUDIO, ENORME Studio, and Smart & Green Design under the theme “The Kuroshio Current”, the Spanish Pavilion is the result of a design selected through a competition organized by Acción Cultural Española. Its connection to the ocean refers to Spain’s national identity, as well as the country’s historical ties with Japan.

The pavilion spans approximately 37,674 square feet, showcasing Spain’s innovation, culture, and productive activity. Over the next six months, companies, regional authorities, and other institutions will use its spaces for meetings, presentations, and forums.

The pavilion features an open and welcoming architecture that doesn’t rely on an imposing façade. It is designed as a landscape that invites visitors into a spacious front void. This space or square is inspired by the Mediterranean spirit, which encourages play, rest, and interaction. As stated by the design team, “We wanted people to sit, relax, meet... almost like sitting by the seashore.”

Gentle steps that simulate sea waves lead visitors to the anteroom of the exhibition, which is called the Plaza del Sol. This space features an LED screen displaying seven video artworks that explore the symbolism of the sun. 

Behind this “digital façade”, the exhibition opens up along a descending ramp that evokes the sensation of a dive. Ultramarine tones decorate this route, which leads to the exit, where a multipurpose room, a shop, and a seafood restaurant are located. 

Located at street level, the exit features a more vivid color palette and a 360º audiovisual installation that channels the festive spirit of Spain and its people. The exit is also connected to The Grand Ring, a vast wooden ring structure that houses the expo’s main facilities, designed by Sou Fujimoto Architects.

In response to the requirement that all structures at the expo be dismantled once the exhibition ends, the Spanish Pavilion was designed with future disassembly and potential reuse in mind. Its construction system relies on natural, locally sourced materials, such as Japanese red cedar wood, simple dry-assembled joints, and the use of a single element to address multiple needs.

Wood is used throughout the portico structure, composed of a double pillar at each end and T-shaped beams, repeated up to forty times at varying heights to shape the sequence of the interior volumes. The choice of material facilitates assembly and reduces the weight of the structure. Its foundation is, thus, simplified on the site, which contributes to minimizing the structure’s environmental footprint.

The design team collaborated with expert craftsmen for various components of the project, such as its colored façade pieces and furniture. Sustainability guidelines were defined with the support of companies specializing in waste management, who collectively advised the process and provided sustainable materials, such as partition panels made from recycled paper and interior finishes made from plastic recovered from fishing nets.

In addition to Plaza del Sol, the pavilion’s visitor experience is divided into three other sections. Corrientes hacia el futuro evokes the feeling of diving into the depths of the sea, with an interior that features audiovisual installations and interactive devices that explore the blue economy and Spain’s relationship with the ocean.
